data.text: This is a great app. I recommend it to everyone. It does exactly what it claims and it is actually free to use. There has been no interruptions from ads during any of the interactions with Norton Genie. It does not constantly interrupt the interactions with ads to upgrade Norton Genie to the "premium" version and it does not have you copy, paste, and submit the email/message text, links, photo to the app, only to reply, "scanning for scams is accessible with the paid premium version only."
data.replyText: Hello! Thanks for taking the time to leave us a valuable feedback. We are delighted to hear that the application is helping our customers without such difficulties. If you would require any help regarding Norton, kindly feel free to reach us on our Facebook at https://m.me/norton or on Twitter athttps://twitter.com/NortonSupport

data.text: I like where this is going but would like to see these features integrated into Norton 360. It should scan email, messages, images without the user having to copy paste or touch them. Copy pasting from email or messages increases the risk of accidentally clicking malicious links or images that lead to malicious websites or tracking images.

Too cumbersome and time-consuming. I for one do not have time to showing you stuff. If you can't block it what good is it. And quite frankly after 30 years with Norton and you charging for things you keep adding is going to turn off a lot of customers. I was led to believe Norton 360 was all I would ever need. But Norton keeps adding expensive add ons'.

It might help people who can't recognize reasonably obvious scam clues, but what it needs is the ability to recognise well designed spam. In particular, it would be a lot more useful if I could upload a full email -- the message text plus the headers -- so that the app could detect when an email was sent from an address other than the one shown as the From. I had one today purportedly from a friend in trouble. But was it really from them or from a scammer wanting me to reply? I can't tell!

so,as I got familiar with genie Norton, I noticed that the more I interacted with it, the better it got. Plus, from what I gather, this app isn't malicious in any kind of way. so if you're a Terminator fan, don't worry, I believe this to be a very informative an influential piece of data.

data.text: AWSOME . It's already detected 3 scams . One was a fake AD block email .2 Scam text messages. I had a different vitus malware by a Good company that didn't detect it. Absolutely great app. If I had to choose one 5 apps to keep this would be on the list

I do not trust Norton Genie. Norton Genie failed to identify TRACK718, a notorious generator of fake tracking documentation for numerous online scams. Search Copilot for "TRACK718" and you get a long accurate report: "Track718 is a fraudulent tracking service that works with scam websites to trick customers and prevent refunds for undelivered orders through fabricated tracking updates12. It is not affiliated with any legitimate shippers like FedEx or USPS. It is a form of social engineering..."

data.text: I just happened to Stumble upon Norton Genie while updating my Norton products and within my first encounter, a suspicious text message which I took a screenshot of and from the screenshot, I shared directly to Norton Genie and within seconds it verified my suspicion, that it was indeed a "SCAM PACKAGE DELIVERY" It then asked me a series of questions 1)did I open the link "NO" 2)Had I given any personal info "NO" 3)Did I download anything "NO" Once the word gets out this will be a Top Paid App.
